citing_paper_authors: Samuel, Brody | Nicholas, Diakopoulos
raw_text: Recent work in this area includes Velikovich et al (2010), who developed a method for automatically deriving an extensive sentiment lexicon from the web as a whole. The resulting lexicon has greatly increased cover age compared to existing dictionaries and can handle spelling errors and web-specific jargon
clean_text: Recent work in this area includes Velikovich et al (2010), who developed a method for automatically deriving an extensive sentiment lexicon from the web as a whole.

citing_paper_authors: Samuel, Brody | Nicholas, Diakopoulos
raw_text: Graph Approach We examine two methods for sentiment detection that of Brody and Elhadad (2010) for detecting sentiment in reviews, and that of Velikovich et al (2010) for finding sentiment terms in a giga-scale web corpus
clean_text: We examine two methods for sentiment detection that of Brody and Elhadad (2010) for detecting sentiment in reviews, and that of Velikovich et al (2010) for finding sentiment terms in a giga-scale web corpus.

citing_paper_authors: Samuel, Brody | Nicholas, Diakopoulos
raw_text: Velikovich et al (2010) constructed a graph where the nodes were 20 million candidate words or phrases, selected using a set of heuristics including frequency and mutual information of word boundaries
clean_text: Velikovich et al (2010) constructed a graph where the nodes were 20 million candidate words or phrases, selected using a set of heuristics including frequency and mutual information of word boundaries.

citing_paper_authors: Samuel, Brody | Nicholas, Diakopoulos
raw_text: On the other hand, the method of Velikovich et al (2010) is based on huge amounts of data, and takes advantage of the abundance of contextual information available in full documents, whereas our do main is closer to that of Brody and Elhadad (2010), who dealt with a small number of candidates and short documents typical to on line reviews
clean_text: On the other hand, the method of Velikovich et al (2010) is based on huge amounts of data, and takes advantage of the abundance of contextual information available in full documents, whereas our domain is closer to that of Brody and Elhadad (2010), who dealt with a small number of candidates and short documents typical to online reviews.

citing_paper_authors: Samuel, Brody | Nicholas, Diakopoulos
raw_text: Algorithm Once the graph is constructed, we can use either of the propagation algorithms of Brody and Elhadad (2010) and Velikovich et al (2010), which we will denote Reviews and Web ,respectively
clean_text: Once the graph is constructed, we can use either of the propagation algorithms of Brody and Elhadad (2010) and Velikovich et al (2010), which we will denote Reviews and Web, respectively.

citing_paper_authors: Song, Feng | Jun Seok, Kang | Polina, Kuznetsova | Yejin, Choi
raw_text: Velikovich et al (2010) use graph propagation algorithms for constructing a web-scale polarity lexicon for sentiment analysis
clean_text: Velikovich et al (2010) use graph propagation algorithms for constructing a web-scale polarity lexicon for sentiment analysis.

citing_paper_authors: Song, Feng | Ritwik, Bose | Yejin, Choi
raw_text: A technique named label propagation (Zhu and Ghahramani, 2002) has been used by Rao and Ravichandran (2009) and Velikovich et al (2010), while random walk based approaches, PageRank in particular, have been used by Esuli and Sebastiani (2007)
clean_text: A technique named label propagation (Zhu and Ghahramani, 2002) has been used by Rao and Ravichandran (2009) and Velikovich et al (2010), while random walk based approaches, PageRank in particular, have been used by Esuli and Sebastiani (2007).

citing_paper_authors: Song, Feng | Ritwik, Bose | Yejin, Choi
raw_text: Much of previous research investigated the use of dictionary network (e.g., WordNet) for lexicon induction (e.g., Kamps et al (2004), Takamura et al (2005), Adreevskaia and Bergler (2006), EsuliandSebastiani (2006), Su and Markert (2009), Mohammad et al (2009)), while relatively less research investigated the use of web documents (e.g., Kaji and Kitsuregawa (2007), Velikovich et al (2010))) .Wilson et al (2005b) first introduced the sentiment lexicon, spawning a great deal of research thereafter

citing_paper_authors: Song, Feng | Ritwik, Bose | Yejin, Choi
raw_text: Howeverin recent years, sentiment lexicons started expanding to include some of those words that simply associate with sentiment, even if those words are purely objective (e.g., Velikovich et al (2010), Baccianellaet al (2010))
clean_text: However in recent years, sentiment lexicons started expanding to include some of those words that simply associate with sentiment, even if those words are purely objective (e.g., Velikovich et al (2010), Baccianellaet al (2010)).

citing_paper_authors: Xufeng, Han | Kota, Yamaguchi | Karl, Stratos | Alyssa, Mensch | Jesse, Dodge | Tamara L., Berg | Alexander C., Berg | Amit, Goyal | Margaret, Mitchell | Yejin, Choi | Hal, Daumé III
raw_text: For edge weights, we use conditional prob abilities between predicates and arguments so that w (p? a):= pr (a|p) and w (a? p):= pr (p|a) .In order to collectively induce the visually descriptive words from this graph, we apply the graph propagation algorithm of Velikovich et al (2010), a variant of label propagation algorithms (ZhuandGhahramani, 2002) that has been shown to beef fective for inducing a web-scale polarity lexicon based on word co-occurrence statistics
clean_text: In order to collectively induce the visually descriptive words from this graph, we apply the graph propagation algorithm of Velikovich et al (2010), a variant of label propagation algorithms (Zhu and Ghahramani, 2002) that has been shown to be effective for inducing a web-scale polarity lexicon based on word co-occurrence statistics.

citing_paper_authors: Raul, Guerra | Amit, Goyal | Hal, Daumé III
raw_text: Examples include constructing polarity lexicons based on lexical graphs from WordNet (Rao and Ravichandran, 2009), constructing polarity lexicons from web data (Velikovich et al 2010) and unsupervised part-of speech tagging using label propagation (DasandPetrov, 2011)
clean_text: Examples include constructing polarity lexicons based on lexical graphs from WordNet (Rao and Ravichandran, 2009), constructing polarity lexicons from web data (Velikovich et al 2010) and unsupervised part-of-speech tagging using label propagation (Das and Petrov, 2011).

citing_paper_authors: Raul, Guerra | Amit, Goyal | Hal, Daumé III
raw_text: In general for graph-based NLP problems; for example, constructing web-derived polarity lexicons (Velikovich et al 2010), top 25 edges were used, and for unsupervised part-of-speech tagging using label propagation (Das and Petrov, 2011), top 5 edges were used
clean_text: For example, constructing web-derived polarity lexicons (Velikovich et al 2010), top 25 edges were used, and for unsupervised part-of-speech tagging using label propagation (Das and Petrov, 2011), top 5 edges were used.

citing_paper_authors: Amit, Goyal | Hal, Daumé III
raw_text: A web-derived lexicon (Velikovich et al,2010) was constructed for all words and phrases using graph propagation algorithm which propagates polarity from seed words to all other words
clean_text: A web-derived lexicon (Velikovich et al, 2010) was constructed for all words and phrases using graph propagation algorithm which propagates polarity from seed words to all other words.

citing_paper_authors: Richard, Socher | Jeffrey, Pennington | Eric H., Huang | Andrew Y., Ng | Christopher D., Manning
raw_text: Recently, (Velikovich et al, 2010) showed how touse a seed lexicon and a graph propagation framework to learn a larger sentiment lexicon that also includes polar multi-word phrases such as? once in alife time?
clean_text: Recently, (Velikovich et al, 2010) showed how to use a seed lexicon and a graph propagation framework to learn a larger sentiment lexicon that also includes polar multi-word phrases such as 'once in a life time'.
